sentences.sentence: We're besotted.
Obsessed.
Slavishly, utterly devoted.On Monday night, the final season of “Succession” won six Emmy Awards, including best drama.

Two of Opinion's resident “Succession” fans, Lydia Polgreen and Adam Sternbergh, reflect on the Roy family's big night:Lydia Polgreen: Oh, man ᅳ hearing that piano riff as “Succession” won its first Emmy of the night and Matthew Macfadyen hugged his castmates and walked up to the stage.
The memories!Adam Sternbergh: It made me want to rewatch the entire series from the beginning.
“Succession” cleaned up exactly as most people thought it would.
I know you're afan, but how much of a fan?Lydia: Besotted.
Obsessed.
Slavishly, utterly devoted.
Watched every minute of it, more than once.
Look, it is my industry (media), and I am a sucker for epic family drama.
I was all in from Episode 1.
You?Adam: Ditto, ditto, ditto.
I do wonder how you think we'll think of it, say, 10 years from now.
How representative of this era is it?Lydia: It's a really good question.

All of the shows I have rewatched long after they ended ᅳ “The Sopranos,” “The Americans,” “Mad Men,” “The Wire” ᅳ are anchored in a very specific moment in history, but they never feel even a tiny bit dated.It also feels meaningful that “Succession” was a funny show in a way that other prestige shows were not.

There were moments of comedy in all the great dramas of peak TV, but none of them were as mordantly funny on a consistent basis in the way “Succession” was.Adam: You could argue that minute for minute, “Succession” is much funnier than “The Bear,” the winner for best comedy.Lydia: I would go further and say that “Succession” is one of the funniest shows to appear on television in the past decade.

To me, prestige TV was once complex one-hour dramas and dramedies of peak HBO, but I think peak TV is now shorter and more narrowly focused shows, like “The Bear” and “Abbott Elementary.” Maybe these shows are a bridge to what's next?
Comedy may be the only plausible reaction to our moment.

How else do we endure?Adam: The entire Emmy telecast definitely had a backward-looking feel, culminating in a valedictory celebration of an all-timer show that aired its final episode all the way back in May 2023.Lydia: It felt like a fitting coda for a great show, winning all the awards on the night when Jeryd Mencken ᅳ whoops, I mean Donald Trump ᅳ romped in the Iowa caucuses.
Lord help us all.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: We’re besotted. Obsessed. Slavishly, utterly devoted.On Monday night, the final season of “Succession” won six Emmy Awards, including best drama. Two of Opinion’s resident “Succession” fans, Lydia Polgreen and Adam Sternbergh, reflect on the Roy family’s big night:Lydia Polgreen: Oh, man — hearing that piano riff as “Succession” won its first Emmy of the night and Matthew Macfadyen hugged his castmates and walked up to the stage. The memories!Adam Sternbergh: It made me want to rewatch the entire series from the beginning. “Succession” cleaned up exactly as most people thought it would. I know you’re afan, but how much of a fan?Lydia: Besotted. Obsessed. Slavishly, utterly devoted. Watched every minute of it, more than once. Look, it is my industry (media), and I am a sucker for epic family drama. I was all in from Episode 1. You?Adam: Ditto, ditto, ditto. I do wonder how you think we’ll think of it, say, 10 years from now. How representative of this era is it?Lydia: It’s a really good question. All of the shows I have rewatched long after they ended — “The Sopranos,” “The Americans,” “Mad Men,” “The Wire” — are anchored in a very specific moment in history, but they never feel even a tiny bit dated.It also feels meaningful that “Succession” was a funny show in a way that other prestige shows were not. There were moments of comedy in all the great dramas of peak TV, but none of them were as mordantly funny on a consistent basis in the way “Succession” was.Adam: You could argue that minute for minute, “Succession” is much funnier than “The Bear,” the winner for best comedy.Lydia: I would go further and say that “Succession” is one of the funniest shows to appear on television in the past decade. To me, prestige TV was once complex one-hour dramas and dramedies of peak HBO, but I think peak TV is now shorter and more narrowly focused shows, like “The Bear” and “Abbott Elementary.” Maybe these shows are a bridge to what’s next? Comedy may be the only plausible reaction to our moment. How else do we endure?Adam: The entire Emmy telecast definitely had a backward-looking feel, culminating in a valedictory celebration of an all-timer show that aired its final episode all the way back in May 2023.Lydia: It felt like a fitting coda for a great show, winning all the awards on the night when Jeryd Mencken — whoops, I mean Donald Trump — romped in the Iowa caucuses. Lord help us all.
